reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This game was given to me by the developer for review purposes. This did not influence my review in any way.

==========================================================
---------------------------------------OVERVIEW-------------------------------------
==========================================================Note: Void Raiders is currently in Early Access. The version reviewed was released 17-MAR-2016 (including hotfix).

Void Raiders is a hectic science-fiction twin-stick shooter with rogue-like elements and great pixel graphics.

==========================================================
----------------------------------------QUALITY-------------------------------------
==========================================================Graphics - Void Raiders has mostly great pixel graphics with a technological theme. It doesn't quite look like cyberpunk, but there's a definite sci-fi feel to everything. From the Lone Invader Tavern" that makes up the sparse main menu

votesTotal: but you get used to it after a while

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What attracted me to Void Raiders was its beautiful cyberpunk pixel art style. With the neon 80s retro futurism style (Which I'm always a sucker for) I was instantly addicted. Thankfully it’s not just a pretty face, going hand in hand with the graphics is the soundtrack. Clearly wearing its Synthwave/Dark Synth influences on its sleeve but mixing elements of Industrial rock and slicing in a Breakbeat edge it complements the hi-octane action perfectly.

I know the difficulty has been mentioned a few times but I personally think it is set at the right, not too easy that it’s a walk in the park and not so hard its off putting to newcomers as the lovely little Goldilocks would say “It’s just right!”

For the price of the game I think there is a wealth of depth here and by the sounds of it will continue to expand on this in the future.  I know a few on here have compared it to other sweet indiegame shooters such as Crimsonlands, Hammerwatch and Nuclear Throne (and I can clearly see why) but for me It brings me back to the classics such as Gauntlet / Chaos Engine / Geometry Wars / Smash TV and even the granddaddy of the twinstick shooters Robotron but then again I am an old fart!

Highly recommended guys if you need to feed your twinstick twitchiness :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a first impression of the game and I will probably write more about it later.

Void Raiders is a top down mouse-aim shooter-RPG with random level layouts and item drops, persistent character progression and lots and lots of bullets.I played a pre-release alpha build and was immediately enamoured of it, and for five bucks, this early access build is an excellent foundation. Though it lacks plot or characterization of any kind at present, it has good enough music and spritework to convey a sense of style: a dark, neon-lit, occasionally rain-soaked metropolis on... Neptune?

It has three playable characters- Boris the Brawler, Tina the Gunslinger and Gudrun the Bladedancer, and of the three thus far I have had the most success with Boris, whose upgrades slowly turn him into a bullet-spewing tank. Tina puts out even more shots with her dual guns and has an entertaining special ability that causes her to spray bullets everywhere around her. Gudrun, with proper use of her blade-dashing and bullet-reflecting, is surprisingly survivable, and has a shotgun for when her sword isn't enough, but if you can't effectively use her sword to intercept incoming shots, she's by far the most fragile of the three.

Stages are split up into floors. On each floor you must obtain a certain number of key items, either these metal boxes with pink lights or these glowing green datacubes, before the elevator to the next floor becomes available. Enemies respawn endlessly, but you get xp for every kill. They drop cash, ammo and the occasional health pickup. Cash can be used to purchase stat-boosting (more damage, higher crit chance, health back on critical hits, etc) items from in-level vendors, one item per vendor, and you also get a choice of three items to buy between floors. However, you don't know what you're getting if you buy the in-level items, and in roguelike fashion, these items are lost when you die.

There's another review on here mentions the somewhat sluggish player movment, noting that you often have no choice but to take the hits"
recommended: but if anything that's the game's only real shortcoming apart from not-yet-added features. However
hoursPlayed: I personally feel like the current level cap of 10 for each character is a tad low- admiteddly
voteText: leveling only gives you skill points

votesHelpful: or at least a high one
votesTotal: as the game still becomes very difficult in later stages. Interestingly
votesFunny: I noticed that the difficulty increases not per stage but rather at certain time intervals in the length of your run- if you waste time
column16: but you might miss out on extra funding and items.\n\nI've played a lot of roguelikes and am glad to see another one with character experience and skills that carry over between runs. I hope that
column19: victory in this game is an eventuallity

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off let me say that this game is extremely fun, and is most definately worth the $5 i spent on it. I honestly was not expecting to much as it seemed a lot like a nuclear throne rip off or something along those lines and did not seem interesting at all, but i said screw it let me try it and see how i like it!" and i honestly dont regret buying this. it is a really fun game to play and it gets fairly addictive.

Now this isnt to say that it does not have its flaws. this is a early access game so of course there are bugs
date: i mean even in fully released games there are bugs everywhere. As of this game nothing is really hugely gamebreaking there are moments where u want to smash your keyboard in because of the annoyingness of some of the mobs but that is the fun part of this game. you dont really know what to expect really. As of this review there are only 3 characters
recommended:
however with 2 customisable trees for each character it adds up to multiple fun ways to play the game. there definetly needs to be more characters / weapons / and levels because after a while killing the same mobs kinda gets old.

Overall though the game is really fun to play so i rate this an 8/10 as far as it being a early access. I definetly recomend you to buy this if you have the $5 and want something entertaining. The creator responds to your feedback and takes into consideration what you say so i see this game having a promising future!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Rogue-type twin stick, very addictive gameplay, and I haven't even listened to the soundtrack yet.  All the best stuff from my 80s and 90s arcade upbringing in one nice package, I haven't had this much fun since Ikari Warriors.  Do yourself a favor and buy it, and support this good effort.

Edit:  I add this part at the end in case any other developers read reviews for other games to try to understand what makes something so popular or attractive to users.  I would say this developer pays an appropriate amount of attention to the visual effects, not so much that they ovewhelm or that the game loses focus, but it makes a really nice paint job" on top of great mechanics (which seem very well-tweaked).

A lot of other games
date: including ones I have bought but not played lately
hoursPlayed: but are just missing that extra variety in the color palette or visual effects to stay up to date with modern games.\n\nHere's a hint -- if the visuals on things like Bejeweled look head and shoulders better than your game
voteText: it needs some shine.  This developer used relatively low-pixel 8-bit style graphics and gave it the right shine to make it do its magic

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good. I already like this infinitely better than Nuclear Throne, which it is very similar to in terms of combat and weapon sounds, because it gives me a chance to not die quickly over and over again because it actually gives me some ♥♥♥♥♥ hit points. Nuclear Throne gives you 8. This game gives you 100+. That is the single only reason that I found NT challenging. Despite giving you so much hp, this game is challenging. Enemy bullets travel fast (too fast), enemies travel fast, and they respawn infinitely on each stage and they respawn often. And that is one of the biggest problems I have with this game is that enemy projectiles travel too fast. You cannot avoid gunfire and will always take massive amounts of dmg. It really does need to be toned down if they want this game to have any shelf life. And I'm not bad, most gunfire/lasers are just unavoidable. The objective is to collect four pink things in the level then the elevator is ready and you backtrack to it to go to the next stage. The game gets increasingly hard from very easy to hard and so on, exactly like in Risk of Rain. Another thing that makes it more enjoyable than Throne is that you can get permanent character skill upgrades, like crit chance and the ability to have a gundrone. K&M controls work great and you even get a nice red laser to help you aim in case you lose your crosshair in the action which you will like in most top down shooters.

Graphics
The graphics are done well although they need to be cleared up because the rooms can get confusing as to what you can or cannot walk over/around. I am often wasting bullets shooting into a pillar that blends into the background or I have to try and decipher how I want to navigate a room while ten guys are wailing on me with lasers.

Sound/Music
Awesome! I love the music and the gunfire booms loudly.

There are some things I hope get fixed up, like how on one stage I was staying locked in one room and running out of ammo because the little white ninja slice guys wouldn't quit respawning and running at me. They need to tone down those guys respawn rate and make them take a little less dmg to kill. Also when the girl character runs out of ammo she just simply wont fire but once every few seconds making her only useful if you have energy for her special move and get lucky and get a ammo drop. The other big problem is that end of level rewards are useless unless you can stack them multiple times. The problem is that the game gets hard very quickly so that's not going to happen and even if it could, end rewards are random. Double end level reward bonuses to fix this.

It's an early access game so of course it needs a lot of work, such as a better UI, better menus, more instructions, more options, more content, more coherent level design for less confusion, more clear item buying during a level so you don't miss it, character improvements, slow down enemy bulets, lessen respawn rate, more clear goals, more varied goals, explanation of why I need to use green build credits to enter certain side areas, and so on. So far they are on the right track and depending how much they put into this game it could turn out awesome.

6.5/10 so far

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very well done and constantly updated/evolving twin-stick shooter.

It's a game where you'll not get much help from within the game but for sure in the community.  The reason I say this is there are lots of pickups that you get and save from run to run that come into play throughout the run and also equipping your 3 raiders.

It's a bit hard at the start to put this together if you dont' know anything [I picked this up day -1] but once you get used to those and understand how they work; you can tweak your raider with skills and items, both initial setup as well round to round.

I've really gotten to like this and it's a shame that it doesn't log time while offline :(  I have way more hours in offline mode as my kids talk to their friends on the account.

It's a great time, it has progression and it's a shmup so what's not to like?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun and frantic top down sci-fi shooter with three playable characters.
Amazing soundtrack that really gets you pumped up to do some damage.

Upgrade your characters as you try to survive.
A perfectly done rogue-lite experience.

Character upgrades carry over, but you can also get power-ups that only last each game you play.
Stack your bonuses to gain increase in health,damage,credits etc.
Enemies attack in waves while maintaining small spawn points throughout the map.
Make your way through each zone to the guided items that will open up gateways to more difficult areas.
Multiple levels/areas.
Some blood and gore.
Intense action that ramps up in difficulty as the run progresses.
Lots of replayability.

A variety of pixelated goodness as each area has it's own unique set of enemies and theme.

The game runs pretty smooth even on my low end processor and graphics card.
Both keyboard and gamepad work well, each bringing a separate experience.

It's as if Geometry Wars met Call of Duty, Re-Loaded and Doom and were in the setting of Mass Effect.
(Yeah, that's the conclusion I came to. It's open to interpretation though.)

All in all, I would highly recommend this game.
9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bliss.          Combine smash hit games Nuclear Throne and Risk of Rain and you get Void Raiders. There are two excellent systems at play that make this game work. First you have the temporary character upgrades/pickups during the gameplay. You are able to purchase one of three upgrades between randomly generated levels and these stay with you until you die. They are pickups such as a thorn halo that hurts enemies close to you or an increased critical chance. These are welcome but incremental, almost anemic, upgrades. They help once you stack 5 or more of each but initially they won't do you much good.

The second system that makes this game work is the permanent character progression. You start with 3 selectable characters and as you play with each they level up. Upon levelling up they get skill points that you can apply to two different skill trees for each character. These are serious improvements and you will likely die a lot at first with each new character. However, once you apply 2 or 3 skill points your character becomes a death-dealing, apocalypse wielding, mayhem spitting machine. To take it one step further for you progression junkies, there are 3 equipment upgrades as well. While beating levels you will earn four different resources and each hardware upgrade uses 2 different, very rare, resources. This will likely be the slowest upgrade path and it seems to be an odd choice at this point given that they appear to be fairly week changes.

This is early access though and the game isn't without it's potential improvements. To be a true classic it needs to tighten up the controls/responses. A real SHMUP needs lightning fast movement and tight controls. The game currently is a little swimmy and the shooting feels off, inaccurate. That might be due to the impossible cursor/aimpoint that is lost in the oversaturated graphics. I'm not a graphics snob and I love pixel art as much as the next guy but I find the lighting, color choice and minimalist art to hurt the experience a little. At the same time the individual art is charming at times and shows real talent. I just think the art direction could benefit from more consistent style and a little more restraint on light effects.

I think this is a true gem in the making. Great work Tryzna83

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Edit: the developers have addressed some of the issues on day 2 after launch. This is promising, and I'll keep playing and will keep my review up to date.
---

Wait to buy and instead wishlist this game, for now. The price is totally great for the product given at this point, but if you are leary of anything that comes with Early Access, I'd totally wait. Although Void Raiders is its own thing, there is alot of influence of Nuclear Throne here (which is wayyy better at this point, but then again its been around a long time and basically created a subgenre spawning games like this one).

Essentially, you get to choose out of three playable characters (more to come) which all have their own stats and unique weapons. Like Nuclear Throne you have a primary and secondary weapon. They all feel different which is good. The cool thing about the characters is that they have metagame permanent RPG-style level up ability with a small tech-tree that you can kind of choose how to build the character (its really limited, but fun none-the-less). Otherwise this is pretty much a spray-and-pray affair.

Pros:
+Price is really cheap for the level of content.
+The fun factor definately increases with time. It starts out really really slow.
+Level up system is fun, although it needs to be modified - currently it can simply be boiled down to a 1st level grind. You can (and I did for a bit) just sit on the first level over and over to grind XP to level up. It may actually be the smart thing to do, idk.

Meh:
=For the boasting about the music, its ok, but considering all the great music in indie gaming; I wouldn't buy the soundtrack.
=The pixel art can be a bit muddy at times. Sometimes its hard to know what is the top of a box and the side, etc. Sometimes the art overall is simple (in particular I am talking about the actual playable character models).

Cons:
-Overall, the game needs more of its own identity. Yeah it seperates itself a bit from Nuclear Throne, but when it does, it mostly just goes into some other mechanic thats been done by some more successful game(s). This can be corrected.
-Most importantly, your character is too slow and/or the bullets are too fast. Even with speed upgrades, many times I just have to take the bullets. There is no sprint or dodge-roll. It seriously eliminates alot of the strategy. It makes it brute force, when it should be anything but.
-There is polish that could be easily done, that needs to be. For example, characters that are non-selectable at the moment should have a tool-tip that says 'coming soon' etc. It can be confusing. Shops apparently are also not available, although it looks like it. I mean, is it a glitch? Is it me? Are they available or not? It would take moments to make a tooltip for these situations. Its still not the best, but the developer's explained the shrines to me.
-The level load times should be reduced (it breaks momentum), and the small 'cutscene' scanning the level is functionless and just wastes time. What are you trying to show us?
-No options menu or graphics options, etc. Found this thanks to dev help
-I get a bit of lag on both my gaming rig and mid-end laptop. No bigs, but it should be noted.

Its cheap, and the content is there but needs further refinement. I will not refund or anything, and look forward to this game further seperating itself from competitors and really becoming its own thing.

Peace,
